checklist.name: Commit messages conform to standards
checklist.description: Well-formatted commit messages make it easy to scan commit history and provide clear, concise information to the reader.

checklist.name: Names and comments do not include spelling mistakes
Items that use amounts encode the unit of measurement.
checklist.description: A variable named something such as timeout_seconds requires less digging around to figure out the unit.

checklist.name: Public methods check the validity of all their arguments at the beginning of the method.
checklist.description: Public methods have to act defensively and assume they'll get passed any range of garbage values. Checking early means that no state changes happen unless the input is all valid.

checklist.name: Storage that's appended to has a retention plan.
checklist.description: If the code appends to some sort of storage, what is the retention policy for that data? Storage that grows and grows can cause operational headaches and system failures.

checklist.name: Mutable data shared across threads is protected from concurrent modifications.
checklist.description: Whenever you have data that can be changed by different threads, you need to use your language's constructs to prevent concurrent modifications.

checklist.name: Data is immutable wherever possible.
checklist.description: Data that is guaranteed to never change is thread-safe and easier to reason about when debugging.

checklist.name: Open connections are closed in the same place
checklist.description: If you open a connection, you should close it. And you should close it in the same block of code that opens it (versus, say, passing it to another method). Use your language's equivalent of Java's finally block

checklist.name: Calls to remote services at a minimum have a timeout. Same with joins or waits on threads.
checklist.description: Any time you pause your program to do something -- wait on a thread or call to a remote service -- you should protect your code with a timeout at a minimum. Even better is the so-called circuit breaker pattern
